results.description:
January 2016: Your 4 Best Shots of 2015  - INCLUDES PRIZES

Special Instructions: Post 4 images that you consider your best images of 2015. All of your images should be of different subjects. All 4 will be judged together as a group, plus one individual image will be chosen from all posted images. You must post 4. If your images do not post together, I will arrange them together in the pool sometime during the month or after the contest closes.

You must either add a title or numbers 1-4 in the caption of each of your images. For this contest, the winners will be chosen by our members, not by the judge of the previous contest. (The Dec winner will judge the Feb contest.) 

Voting instructions will be announced on 2/1/16 after the contest ends. For this contest, you must vote to win (but not for your own images.) Every member (whether participating in the contest or not) will be permitted to submit one ballot. 

Winners must be members at of the contest on 1/31/16 and until voting ends. Otherwise your name will disappear from under the photo (if for example, your trial membership ends) and we won't know who to vote for.

BONUS:  At least two Prizes of one-year free membership.  Winners will not have to pay dues the next time they come due! 

If this contest is successful, with lots of participation by members (both entries and voting) it may become an annual event.

(see upcoming themes below)

Please check contest rules if you have not already done so: http://www.meetup.com/pittsburgh-photo-safari/messages/boards/thread/32726552 

A reminder that special instructions will appear on the contest album's cover image or its comments when the contest opens.

The photo album will open at 3:15 a.m. on the 1st of the month. Photos submitted after midnight on the last day of the month will not be eligible. If you post a photo and change your mind, you may delete it and replace it with a different photo before the deadline. If more than 2 photos are submitted, the first 2 will be judged; the 3rd will not.

________


FUTURE THEMES through June 2016:

I may add suggestions for some topics. You are free to use them or not. However, if something is marked with SPECIAL INSTRUCTIONS, those must be followed.

February 2016: In the Pink   Suggestions: The phrase "in the pink" usually means in good health or spirits. You can interpret the theme that way or have the main subject or most of your image be a shade of pink.

March 2016: Money

April 2016: Storm


May 2016: Junk  A mid-May meetup will give you the opportunity to take photos of lots of junk.  Details to be announced in April.


June 2016: Fabric or Textile Although not required, macro might work well on images of textiles.
results.how_to_find_us: Online event, no actual meeting.
results.name: JANUARY 2016: YOUR 4 BEST SHOTS OF 2015

group.name: The Pittsburgh Photo Safari Meetup Group

results.description:
The Monthly Theme album is an online submission album.  Read the monthly theme and then submit photos that fit the theme ALL MONTH LONG online.  There is no formal meetup for this album.

Interpret the theme as you wish. Post up literal or figurative photos. It's all about being challenged by a specified theme!

This album is not open for critiques.  If you want your photo critiqued, you may post it here if it fits the monthly theme, and then post in in the Monthly Critique Album where it will be open for constructive criticism.

For more info:

http://www.meetup.com/pittsburgh-photo-safari/boards/thread/28924022
results.how_to_find_us: Read the monthly theme and then submit photos ALL MONTH LONG!  There is no formal in person meetup.
results.name: January, 2016 Theme Album: ROAD SIGNS

group.name: The Pittsburgh Photo Safari Meetup Group

results.description:
Polar Bear Plunge at Mon Wharf on New Years (a long hike off of a short pier)

My 10th YEAR!!!


When: Friday, January 1st NEW YEARS DAY!


Time: 9am  9:25am get ready! 9:30am Jump IN! 9:31 crawl out of the MON RIVER! Brrr!!!

Where: Mon Wharf Parking Lot

Meet: On the right hand side where they are Jumping in. LOOK FOR THE FLORESCENT ORANGE BIKE FLAG!!! at 9AM!

How will you find US: Look for Guy in Santa Hat with Red and Black Striped Robe (Santa Frank aka BIG KAHUNA) or LOOK FOR THE FLORESCENT ORANGE BIKE FLAG!!! at 9AM!


Cost: FREE or $20 getting a Polar Bear Club T-shirt (absolutely worth it, Buying the T Shirt benefits project bundle up! and gives you BRAGGING RIGHTS! T-shirt info at the bottom!


For more info: Pittsburgh Polar Bear Clubhttp://www.projectbundleup.com/PolarBearJump/index.html

River plunge takes place at 9:30 AM onNew Year's Day - January 1stDirections to Mon Wharf: Go to Wood street and turn towards River at Entrance of Fort Pitt Blvd and Wood Street you will see Entrance to MON Wharf

Looking for a few crazy Men/Women to make sure the New Year Starts off right! I've done this 7 of the last 8 years and look how I turned out! ;-)

Heads ups, you don't have to jump in yourself we need people to hold towels and laugh at us and TAKE PICS! (although the craziness is infective, if you are a towel holder about 80% jump in the next year!)

I'm doing the New Year's Polar Bear Plunge and might as well see who else is crazy enough to jump in the Monongahela on New Years Day with me.

Reminder Polar Bear Plunge is Sunday, New Years Day Jan 1st at Mon Warf at 9am official jump in is at 9:30. Buy a project bundle up T-shirt for $10. Usually about[masked] people this year might be more cause of the warm temps.

I'll be there in my Santa Hat and Red n Black Striped Robe. Afterwards a bunch of us are going to Penny's Diner in Southside afterward. If you find me good, if not find me at Penny's Diner in Southside for Breakfast. The Polar Bear Plunge is well worth doing, and this way your year starts off where you've done something completely weird and different.


ADVICE:1. GET THERE BEFORE 9AM it gets crowded fast!!!2. Have Blankets and a change of shorts, t shirts and socks3. There are safety personnel there.4. You'll have to set your stuff down leave valuables in your car.5. Drag someone else down there even if they aren't jumping then they can be towel/blanket holders and someone needs to laugh at us.6. Channel 4 news is a sponsor of this so you have a chance of being on the news.

*****************************Additional Advice from previous years...We jump from the Mon Wharf Parking directly across from Station Square.....and they leave the wharf parking entrance open...it'll look closed and unmanned, but the chain will be down for parking entrance in fact, there is usually a line of cars trying to get in so try to make it BEFORE 9am!

******If the wharf is closed due to flooding****


The official back up location is near the science center on the North Side. If so, at the wharf entrance on Ft Duquesne Blvd, there will be someone redirecting folks to the alternate location.

We park and meet on the Mon wharf, across the river from Station Square. Folks typical wear sweats , jacket, heck even a bath robe over their swim duds, and old shoes.

I'll be there by 9AM and we start to gather along the shore line. At 9:25 or so, we start getting our "beach wear" exposed and at 9:30 a whistle blows and folks start piling in! There's typically a rope and volunteers on the rivers edge to help folks in and out of the water and crazy as this sounds, it's all done with some safety in mind.

Cheers Santa Frank ;-) PS. We usually go to Deluca's Diner in the Strip Afterwards! See you at DeLuca's in the Strip 2015 Penn Ave, Pittsburgh, PA 15222 afterwards!

PPS. If you want to buy a Polar Bear Club Shirt Early so you don't have to wait in line to buy it. http://www.projectbundleup.com/PolarBearJump/index.html(fyi, they usually have the t-shirt link avail sometime after Dec 10th)
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Frank (Big Kahuna) with FLORESCENT ORANGE BIKE FLAG!!! at 9AM!
results.name: Polar Bear Plunge! New Years Day! Mon Wharf! 9am!

results.description:
*This event is cross posted with the Pittsburgh Hiking Meetup and Pittsburgh Adventure Lovers (PAL) club.*

Joanne from Pittsburgh Hiking Meetup has graciously requested our participation in her event of hiking through the connector of two local favorite parks, Duff Park and Pleasant Valley Park. Please see the description below and enjoy!

"Meet at Duff Park parking lot. This will be an intermediate hike with several hills and approximately 8-10 miles of hiking. Please dress in layers, bring snack and plenty of liquids.

If you RSVP Yes and then change your mind, please be sure to change your RSVP. I will check before I leave my house since I live close by.

Happy Holidays!!"
results.name: Duff Park with connector to Pleasant Valley Park

group.name: Hiking and Hanging out in Westmoreland County

results.description: Meetup at REI in South Side Works nominally at 10:45 AM, with the ride leaving at 11 AM. More information - http://membership.ohiorivertrail.org/index.php/2-uncategorised/175-icycle-bicycle

results.description:
This is the album to use if you want your shots to be critiqued. Please don't upload to this album unless you are prepared for feedback. 

All photos posted to this album are open to constructive criticism. You do not have to add a caption or comment to say that your photo is open to criticism.

OTR: "Open for Retouching" -  If you add OTR to a caption or comment, you are agreeing that it's okay for someone to download your photograph and retouch it. Retouching will only take place if you label it as OTR.  Otherwise no one is to assume you want your photo retouched.  

NEVER download and retouch a photo without OTR (or Open to Retouching) being in the comments. It you retouch a photo without permission and put it back on the site, that retouched photo will be immediately removed.


* For the Critiquers...please be polite when you post critiques. As with all opinions they can be taken harshly when not intended that way. Make sure you re-read your comments before you post them and make sure they are as clear as possible. 

Remember to write constructive criticisms.  Tell the photographer how an image could have been improved when taking the photo and/or how to enhance it to improve it.  Your critique should not be a long list of negative qualities, but rather, a few suggestions for improvement.


Although  the official event time is 7:00 pm, the album will not open until 10 pm.
results.name: Monthly Critiques - January, 2016

results.description:
Start the year off right with one of this year's Oscar shortlist for Best Foreign Language Feature.

Theeb is a thrilling epic adventure set in 1916 in the land of Lawrence of Arabia. This Jordanian award-winner reveals the Arab revolt against the Ottoman Turks through the eyes of its young title character, a Bedouin boy who learns lessons in family, loyalty and resourcefulness when he and his brother are enlisted to find water for a British officer on long, dangerous journey. 

The riveting saga is part coming-of-age tale and part wondrous “Bedouin Western,” with a revealing elemental heart. Jordan's Oscar entry and opening night film of the 2015 Silk Screen Film Festival. (In Arabic with subtitles)


Naji Abu Nowar | United Arab Emirates, Qatar,Jordan, UK | 2014 | 100 min

Film screens at 7:30, meet in lobby beforehand.

More info and trailer:

http://cinema.pfpca.org/films/theeb
results.name: THEEB

results.description:
Join us at Swisshelm most Friday nights for contra dances. This is a recurring meetup, and we will try to cancel if there is a week without a dance, but double check the schedule at www.pittsburghcontra.org which is always up-to-date.

Dances are Fridays at Swisshelm Community Center, 8pm-11pm with a beginner's lesson at 7:30.

$7 for students, $10 for the rest of us folks.

Contra dancing is hungry business, if you'd like to bring a snack to share at the break, please do!

No experience necessary, no partner necessary, just bring your feet and a smile.

Please note that most of our community is not using Meetup.com. Though it may look like nobody is attending, rest assured that there will be lots of people at the dance!

This is the plan for tomorrow - new members are always welcome if you want to check it out. French in Action is a lively video method for learning French - based on native French expressions and invention.

I will provide vocabulary and lesson handouts in class as well as supplement the audio exercises with specific homework.

Materials will be distributed online for participating members.

Just a reminder: if you cannot come for whatever reason please be so kind as to cancel your RSVP online. That helps let me not print so many docs. And gives your spot them someone else. Merci!

results.description:
This is the intro and prerequisite class for all of our following classes. You must start on week 1. The Common Fencing class is usually limited to 12 -14 people per class. If you pay for your classes up-front you are guaranteed a seat on your day of choice. Additional sessions, walk-ins, and make-ups are subject to space in the class/permission from the instructor. 
*Common drilling has a larger class size.

YOU MUST REGISTER AND PAY FOR THIS COUSE ON OUR WEBSITE!
More info and registration link here: www.pittsburghswordfighters.com/brokenplow/classes/cfcd

Cost
The 8-week intro course is $100 (equal to two months of base membership).  The base membership entitles you to the following: Access to all open floor sessions, access to all Common Fencing or Common Drilling classes, discounts on gear from our partner vendors (when ordered through our group orders), and access to all Broken Plow events (discount if there is a charge to attend).

You may also take classes for $15/class or open floor session. Once you complete Common Fencing you can substitute Rapier for the Common Drilling course or take both for a small up-charge. Other classes are being phased in during the spring of 2016.

The Tuesday classes are also held on Saturdays; however, the cycle weeks are staggered. You are welcome to attend class both days for no additional charge.

What to Wear & What to Bring
Please wear comfortable clothes. Workout clothes are highly recommended. Athletic shoes are a must and wrestling shoes are what many of our fighters wear.

We will provide the basic gear and the swords for this class. Loner gear is prioritized for the Common Fencing class over the Drilling class. We encourage people to begin getting basic gear once they have committed to more than three months. We can help you with this process and provide group discounts. 

Longsword Class Structure
Saturday Timeline: 
10:00pm - Open Floor & Krav Maga/Self Defense Class
11:00am - Group Warmup/PT & Breakout Classes (Common Fencing, Drilling, Etc)

Common Fencing is a class that is designed to introduce students to the basics of sword combat, footwork, terminology, and other fighting techniques. The CF class is an 8-week course that prepares you for the next class. Once you complete the 8-week course you may move on to the Common Drilling class. The drilling class is approximately 20 weeks of cycling drills, games, and slow sparring designed to teach/reinforce the fundamentals of German sword combat. Eventually students may move into higher level classes while still using the drilling class to practice and hone their skills.

Beginning in January we are adding a Rapier class; however, common fencing is required before you may begin other weapon classes.
results.how_to_find_us: We are on the corner of Butler & Bridge street. Our school is on the 2nd floor. The stairs are to the left when entering the lobby.
results.name: Common Fencing - Week 1 (of 8)

results.description:
Let's welcome the New Year -- as well as many recent members!

And if you joined this meetup group a while ago, but haven't had much free time, perhaps you can join us this time.


This event will bring together lots of new people (which will also help with future introductions) as well as incorporate flexibility tailored to the interests of the group.


This event will begin inside the wonderful Carnegie Museum of Art Café so people can quickly meet and socialize as well as get coffee/tea or quick lunch.  Please note that the Carnegie Museum of Art Café does not require museum admission which makes it particularly suitable as we plan the rest of the afternoon and evening.

Because we're expecting a large turnout for this event (although we'll have a better idea once we know the weather forecast, etc.), we'll incorporate some flexibility. 


We realize that while some people may only have a few hours of free time, others may enjoy spending the afternoon or early evening checking out all of the exhibits or perhaps meeting for an optional dinner.


After we're done meeting/eating at the Carnegie Museum of Art Café, we'll gauge of the interests of everyone (perhaps 20-30+ people) and the possibility of smaller groups (5-20 people) exploring the following options from 1-5 PM.

Option A -- Spend the afternoon inside the many galleries and exhibits of the Carnegie Museum of Art http://www.cmoa.org/ and Carnegie Museum of Natural History http://www.carnegiemnh.org/


Option B -- Walk over to the nearby Phipps Conservatory Winter Flower Show http://phipps.conservatory.org

Option C -- Walk over to check out the beautiful holiday decorations of the 27 Nationality Rooms inside the Cathedral of Learning http://www.nationalityrooms.pitt.edu followed by several other interesting stops featuring notable works of art in Oakland.

At 4:40 PM, everyone can reconvene inside the Carnegie Museum Hall of Architecture to check out the annual Carnegie Trees: Winter Wonders and remarkable 16th century Neapolitan presepio exhibits which are accompanied by beautiful holiday music.  If life is enjoying simple pleasures, this is one of the most calming and beautiful spaces for people of all ages to enjoy during the holidays. http://www.cmoa.org/visit/holidays/ Please note that as a courtesy, the Carnegie Museum often lets visitors in for free 20 minutes or so before the museum closes at 5 PM.

So this 4:40-5 PM will be a great opportunity to check out this exhibit and get some great photos!

At 5 PM, people can discuss if they'd to have dinner at a nearby restaurant such as The Porch in Schenley Plaza.

Another option would be to eat at the Phipps Conservatory Café since the Phipps Winter Light Garden and Flower Show is open to 11 PM. So anyone choosing Option B in the afternoon is certainly welcome to re-enter Phipps later on without additional charges.

Because aspects of this Meetup involve checking the holiday-themed nature of various locations in Oakland, please note the following:

The last day for the Carnegie Museum's annual exhibits Carnegie Trees: Winter Wonders http://www.cmoa.org/visit/holidays/ and Neapolitan presepio will be Monday January 11.


The last day for the annual Phipps Conservatory Winter Light Garden and Flower Show http://phipps.conservatory.org/exhibits-and-events/featured-event.aspx?eventid=403 will be Sunday January 10.


The last day for the annual holiday decorations http://www.nationalityrooms.pitt.edu/tours/holiday-tours of the 27 Nationality Rooms inside the Cathedral of Learning http://www.nationalityrooms.pitt.edu will be Saturday January 16. 

So while this Meetup event is being planned to allow some flexibility, we certainly encourage everyone to check out these exhibits on other dates if it might be more convenient. And perhaps some smaller groups could be arranged if you'd like to suggest some date(s) in the comments section below.

In terms of Admission Charges, we'll see if anyone has memberships (e.g., Carnegie Museums, Phipps) which allow them to bring guests in for free or additional discounts. But otherwise, here are the normal prices and discount offers.

Admission for Carnegie Museum (please note that we expect a nice discount so it should be about $10 depending on how many from the Meetup show up and their museum memberships which allow guests) Otherwise the regular admission prices are as follows: $19.95 for Adults; $14.95 for Seniors  (65+); $11.95 for Students with ID/Children age 3–18; and Free for Members/Children under 3. There are also a number of discounts (e.g., Military, AAA Member, PAT Monthly Transit holder, ACCESS, WQED member, various companies, teachers, Pitt/CMU/Point Park/Chatham/Carlow students) available by visiting http://www.cmoa.org/discounts/ 


Admission for Phipps $15 for adults; $14 for seniors and students, and $11 for children (ages 2 – 18). While Phipps Members and kids under 2 enter free.

Admission for Nationality Rooms inside the Cathedral of Learning $4 for adults and $2 for Youth.

Stay Tuned for updates!
results.how_to_find_us: The Meetup begins inside the Carnegie Museum of Art Café (which doesn't require the museum admission fee) from 12-1 PM. The Meetup continues through 5-6 PM or later with various options described below, including dinner or beautiful evening at Phipps
results.name: New Year Welcome, You Decide -- Carnegie Museums, Phipps, & More!

results.description:
Take your yoga practice outdoors...no mats required! Our Outdoor Discovery School instructors will guide you on a rejuvenating 3 to 4 mile hike on the South Ridge of North Park. During the hike, we'll break occasionally to take a few standing poses and tension tamers, led by experienced yoga instructor, Jen. Our yoga hike will conclude with a seated guided relaxation.

This outing is suitable for those new to yoga, and is designed for all levels of fitness, so come join us for an energizing experience you won't want to miss.

NOTE: The description on L.L.Bean.com calendar is incorrect. Please refer to this Meetup's description above.

Thank you for your interest in our free "Yoga Hike." L.L.Bean has a centralized reservation system. To guarantee your space, you must first confirm your reservation on our new centralized reservation system, and if appropriate, fill out a participant agreement. Please visit www.llbean.com/pittsburgh, find this event on the "Event Calendar", and register. We look forward to seeing you!

Activity Level: 
Physical Ability/Cardiovascular Demand: Easy 
Level of Experience: Intro

What to Bring: 
Dress comfortably for both hiking and yoga 
Hiking Boots or Trail Shoes 
Day Pack 
Water to stay hydrated 
Snacks 
Completed and signed L.L.Bean participant agreement--> Click Here

Optional: Optics, Lip Balm, Camera, Walking Stick or Trekking Poles, Personal Medicines

Minimum Age 8: This outing is open to ages 8 and above. Children 8 to 14 years of age need to be accompanied by a participating adult. Children 15 to 17 years old can participate alone after their parent has signed the L.L.Bean participant agreement for minors. 

Need help preparing for your next adventure? Visit L.L.Bean Store at Ross Park Mall and ask to speak with an Outdoor Product Specialist. L.L.Bean will fit you with the right clothing and gear for all of life's adventures.

L.L.Bean Store at Ross Park Mall 
1000 Ross Park Mall Drive (Map) 
Pittsburgh, PA  15237 
L.L.Bean Outdoor Discovery Schools 
<a href="http://llbean.com/"></a>
results.name: Yoga Hike for the New Year!

results.description:
The History of Anointing & Laying On Hands In Wexford, PA presented by Rev. Nancy Gouch, BCRS, CAC, FCCI, LSH With the Center for Aromatherapy Research and Education

 2 - 5 p.m. 2 CE’s (NCBTMB) 

Hosted by Danielle McNally 

Call Danielle directly at[masked] for directions. Once we speak on the phone I will email you the link to reserve your seat. There is a $40 fee to attend this class and reserve your seat. All fee's are paid to the instructor. There are 2 C.E.U earned by attending this class approved by the NCTBMB

Join us to learn about and sample:• Oils for healing, cleansing, and holy anointing are mentioned more than 500 times in the Bible.• Aloes, Cassia, Frankincense, Galbanum, Hyssop, Balm, Spikenard, Cedarwood, Myrrh, and many more.• Moses used them to protect the Israelites from disease.• Mary and Joseph used them to keep baby Jesus and themselves healthy.• Modern Science finds  some of them to be as effective as antibiotics and to promote overall health, vitality and longevity.• 

Come learn, enjoy, share and experience these holy healing oils. Come and be anointed.

“And they went out…and they anointed with oil many that were sick and healed them.” Mark 6:12-13

The Center for Aromatherapy Research and Education
results.how_to_find_us: Because this event will be held in my home, please contact me for directions.
results.name: The History of Anointing & Laying On Hands

results.description:
Offered by Rebekah Gamble, HP, through Embody Healing, LLC. I am offering the course An Introduction to Shamanic Practice as a one year in person class in 2016 for $10 a class in response to community needs. This event page is for the free informational meeting so people can ask questions, see the content of the class, flip through the student guide and the text/work books, meet me personally, and see if this is something they want to do.

The class will meet once a month for twelve months. Participants will partake in discussions, assignments on their own time, and have experiences that will give them foundations in shamanic practice. Several different kinds of certifications are available at the completion of the program.

It is my hope that this opportunity will help people with their own healing work, their own spiritual path, help provide direction and information, and help provide the education necessary for members of our community to be safer when choosing practitioners and participating in the shamanic community.

This is the only time I will be presenting basic info, as the course will start January 16 with it's first meeting, and after that we will not be accepting new additions to the class because they will simply be too far behind.

So come on down, ask your questions, meet cool people, and see if this is something that will help you on your path.

Love to you.
results.name: Informational Meeting for Shamanism Class

results.description:
Let us come together to build a community of meditators and spread the benefits of meditation among Pittsburghers. So come and join with us in a Joyful meditation for health and happiness and tell the whole city "I Meditate Pittsburgh." :-)

There are no prerequisites and all above 12 yrs of age are welcome to join. Consider telling your friends and bring them along.

Event will be simple. We will start with some introduction to meditation, do some gentle stretches and have a guided meditation with the group. At the end we will share our experiences and open floor for questions and discussions. You can also ask any questions you may have in the beginning or email us now.

Please RSVP for the event and we look forward to seeing you.

results.description:
Join us on the first Sunday of 2016 to drum in the new year with Jim Donovan! Jim's theme will be "Make taking impeccable care of yourself non-negotiable." Please bring your own sound maker: all manner of drum, boom whacker, shaker, and homemade rhythm-makers welcome!

Jim Donovan is an is an award winning educator, performer, motivator, and multi-platinum recording artist from the rhythmically infused band Rusted Root. Jim is a faculty member at St. Francis University where he teaches courses in World Music, African Music, and Hand Drumming. He also offers workshops on consciousness transformation, healing, personal growth, wellness, and creating community. This is the fourth year we've done this - Jim always leaves us present, centered, and feeling alive!

Then after Fellowship some of us will gather for an informal (non-Jim) drum circle session, please stick around!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L-a8BHzILVE
results.name: Drum in the New Year with Jim Donovan

Join us for meditation, refreshments, and discussion at the Pittsburgh Shambhala Center on Sunday mornings!

  10:30 – 11:30 am:  Meditation instruction and sitting
  11:30 – noon:  Discussion, then tea and refreshments

First time visitors to the Center are encouraged to arrive a few minutes before 10:30 am to become familiar with the space and to determine their preferred sitting posture (on a cushion or on a chair).

Please note that occasionally, because of holidays or conflicts with another programs, there may be a change in the regular schedule — so it’s always good to check the calendar before you come.

results.description:
Hi All,

We're meeting at 11:00AM at the tennis court of Schenley Park  and will play 2 hours or more.
If there are some people who want to play some tennis, please bring your racket and let's play together.

This is the event for all levels.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Here is some guide I want to share with members. 


 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 TENNIS MEETUP RULES

1. Always RSVP before you come to the event. This helps in organizing and for reserving the courts. Note, without RSVP you may not have a spot.

2. If you RSVPed "Yes" and later decided to not come, please change the RSVP to "No" so the first member on the waiting list can get your spot.

3. Members are expected to arrive on time and stay for the duration. If you expect to be late more than 15 minutes, please send a text message to the posted organizer's phone number.

4. We will practice and always play a game - doubles or singles, depending on the number of members who come to the event.

5. The organizer will try to pair the teams based on skill levels but this may not always be possible and the pairing may be on a first-come-first-serve basis.

6. If a member is on the waiting list they can still come, however they may have to wait for courts to become available.
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

  Jason,
results.name: Sunday morning tennis for all levels - Schenley

results.description: A perfect movie for entrepreneurs like us! :-) A story of a family across four generations, centered on the girl who becomes the woman who founds a business dynasty and becomes a matriarch in her own right. Facing betrayal, treachery, the loss of innocence and the scars of love, Joy becomes a true boss of family and enterprise in a world of unforgiving commerce. Allies become adversaries and adversaries become allies, both inside and outside the family, as Joy's inner life and fierce imagination carry her through the storm she faces. Starring Jennifer Lawrence and Bradley Cooper.

During the month of January, we will study Hiragana and Katakana, Japanese writing. This is good for people who want to start a new language at the start of the year! Starting February we will start at the beginning of the book; doing introductions and basic sentence structure.


We use the book "Japanese for Busy People" kana version 3, first of the series.

If you want to get the workbook that goes with this book, it is only for studying Hiragana and Katakana.


We always meet on Sundays in the small meeting room at the Squirrel Hill Library.

results.description:
Please sign up if you're planning on playing and bring your favorite games!  Newbies are very welcome.  We have some great teachers to help you get started on your gaming adventure.  Let us know when you sign up what game(s) you'll be bringing.  On Sundays there is plenty of free parking on the side streets and even right on Murray.  Crazy Mocha serves great coffee, specialty drinks, snacks and pastries.  They do allow us to bring food in if we take our trash with us. We usually play all day, break for dinner around 6:00, then it's back to gaming until everybody poops out. 

Incidentally, many of our regular players no longer bother to sign up (but I really wish they would!), so if it looks like only  one or two people are coming, there could actually be quite a few more.  Remember, I will always cancel a game Meetup if we aren't gaming that day, so you won't be sitting there all by yourself waiting for a friend.    And please, remember to change your rsvp to no if you can't make it that day!

$1.00 will be charged to help cover the fee Meetup charges and to buy games for the group.  Join us and let the games begin!!!

results.description:
This coming Sunday we will be having a different type of event.

We have had debate watch parties, flyering/sign events, phone banks and even a party  --- but now we are going to educate ourselves!This is in two steps.

First watch the video below in 1998 of Bernie giving Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, hell about insane speculation on Wall St. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ca-GncBz60M

And this video in 2009 of Bernie telling Timothy Geithner, Secretary ofthe Treasury, that the crooks we were bailing out should be fired.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MnoI9RsQ_wc

And this video in 2007 of Bernie talking to Hank Paulson about the disparity between the middle class and the rich.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J-BlKGU-NEs

Second, join us at the Manor Theater, 1729 Murray Ave., in Squirrel Hill,to watch the movie "The Big Short."  Which, in entertaining form, illustrate sall the greed and fraud that Bernie is our Old Testament prophet warning us about.  On Sunday, Jan. 2nd by 2PM.  After the movie we will adjourn to a nice Jewish deli, Smallman St. Deli,1912 Murray Ave., across the street to talk it over.

RSVP   See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: The Manor is just a block down from the intersection of Forbes & Murray in Squirrel Hill.
results.name: Bernie Goes to the Movies

results.description:
We will be using "Japanese for Busy People" book 2 version 3.   As usual, we'll meet in Classroom C.


This is a combination of "Beginner 2" and Intermediate 1" levels from last year.


Let's try to figure out how we can improve upon what we are learning so that we can make it both more interactive and at the same time begin to really use our language skills.  Do we want to try having more quizzes?  Interactive dialog?  Roleplaying?
results.how_to_find_us: We are in Classroom C not far from the elevator.

results.description:
An intermediate/ conversation class.

Hi All,

The text book for this class is An integrated approach to inter.mediate Japanese.
This class will be from 4:00 pm to 5:00 pm.

The location is the meeting room C of the Carnegie library squirrel hill.
Please RSVP and let me know if you have any questions.

Let's try to think up some interesting ways to improve upon what we are learning.  Should we be taking regular quizzes or doing some other in class practice?  

Last week we left off at the end of Lesson 5 and ready to move on to Lesson 6.  If there is anything anyone would like to cover outside of the book or on any other topic, also please let us know.

results.description:
Dreaming is cloaked in mystery. Mystery unveiled reveals the interconnectedness in this cosmic dream we are all co-creating.
There are stories to be told, treasures to be discovered and blessings to be shared from deep within our selves.
I had a shamanic dream with a bear some nights ago and want to gather with others to decipher our dreamtime mysteries which are filled with as many synchronicities and connections as our waking life.
Dreaming is a time of rest. When our minds are kissed with the ancienct symbols of life's expressions, we find our truth. Sharing our dreams helps us to discover our story and reveals clarity for our minds.
For this sacred gathering, please bring dreams that you remember, from now until January 3rd. Write them down so you remember as much detail as you can.
Dreams are a mystery and have multiple purposes which I am excited to discuss and explore.
Sharing dreams is a traditional community event in many cultures. If you have any thing else you feel called to share for this gathering, please do ))))♥((((
results.name: Dreamtime Discovery

results.description:
An ordinary British couple vacationing in Switzerland suddenly find themselves embroiled in a case of international intrigue when their daughter is kidnapped by spies plotting a political assassination. This fleet and gripping film is the first of the early thrillers the Master of Suspense, Alfred Hitchcock, made during the fertile phase of his career spent at the Gaumont-British Picture Corporation. 

Besides affirming Hitchcock’s genius, it gave the brilliant Peter Lorre his first English-speaking role, as a slithery villain. With its tension and gallows humor, it’s pure Hitchcock, and it set the tone for such films as The 39 Steps and The Lady Vanishes. - Criterion

Alfred Hitchcock | 1934 | UK | 75 min

Part of the January Sunday Night Series Hitchcock Classics

Film shows AT 8PM, Meet in lobby beforehand.
results.name: Hitchcock's original 1934 THE MAN WHO KNEW TOO MUCH

results.description:
2 Rules for the meet up:

1) No solicitation of services *cool if someone comes to you but consultants/lawyers/coaches beware, any sales pitches and you'll have to find a new Monday ritual

2) Make sure to state whether what you are saying is an opinion or fact (both very much welcome) so to not confuse anyone about where the point of view comes from

Location change: Repair The World - 6022 Broad St. (Around the corner from Zeke's Coffee

Share or listen to ideas but don't be fooled this is not startup therapy or feeding the ego this is about getting to work and removing the obstacles to make your idea a reality.

All entrepreneurs are welcome and it's not uncommon for us to have musicians, artists, chefs, writers, developers, renovators, or just about anyone else you can think of join the conversation.

results.description:
Entrepreneurs helping each other. Bring your ideas, questions and experiences. Providing face-to-face help and feedback for your business in bite-sized chunks.

This meetup is right after the Unstuck Entrepreneur Meetup http://www.meetup.com/unstuckmondaymeetup/ which is right there at Repair the World from 8-9AM. Think about coming to BOTH!


After meeting outside in the lobby of Repair the World / Alpha Lab Gear / Thrill Mill, we adjourn upstairs to Alpha Lab Gear.

This meetup is run by an experienced entrepreneur who started a business, ran it for over 20 years and successfully exited to a public company. He now keeps busy mentoring for a nationally recognized accelerator, reviewing business plans/pitches for investors and consulting for businesses & non-profits. When asked “why do a meetup?” he says he is looking to “pay it forward” by helping people make less mistakes than he made.
results.name: Entrepreneur Monday Morning Roundtable - Entrepreneurs Helping Each Other

Jan. 4: Gerri

results.description:
Come and play ukulele with us at the Unitarian Universalist Church of the North Hills on the first and third Mondays of each month. All levels of play are welcome, and we are novice-friendly. Some people who come have never even held a ukulele, and if you contact Sandy ahead of time, she will bring an extra ukulele for you to try. Try Ukulele.... It's Really Fun!

Music is usually selected from "The Daily Ukulele... 365 Songs for Better Living," by Liz and Jim Beloff. This book is readily available at music stores, book stores, and Amazon.com.  Sometimes members bring other music to play (bring 15 copies to share). We play seated at a large conference table. Bring a table-top music stand if you have one.

Snacks and libations to share are welcome.

For more information, contact Sandy at [masked]

Directions to the Church: Take I279 North to Wexford exit. Turn right at the end of the exit. Right at the light onto Brandt School Road. Right onto West Ingomar Road to 2359. Note: Watch for the large Church sign and turn right, then you will follow a narrow road back through the trees to the Church. We meet in a room just inside the door. If you are driving North from Pittsburgh on I-279, take Exit 8 Camp Horne Road, Go north and then take Rochester Road. West Ingomar Road is just past the Franklin Inn (turn right and then a quick left, and the Church driveway is in sight on your left.

Look for this sign. Note: it is lit at night
results.name: 1st Monday Ukulele in North Hills

results.description:
First class of 2016!

This is one of our weekly sessions. Beginners' hour starts at 7:00 with instruction on basic footwork and formations, allowing everyone to participate in some fun social dances. From about 8:00 until 9:15, we have a Social Class - the focus is on more experienced dancers and complex dances, but beginners are encouraged to stay and watch, and participate in some of the simpler dances.

Beginners are always welcome, no partner necessary. (In fact, you will be encouraged to dance with more experienced dancers rather than with other beginners.)

The $7.00 fee per person for each class covers the cost of renting the room and paying the teacher. First-time attendees and dues-paying members pay only $5. We do not want price to be an obstacle for anyone attending class. Beginners have the option of purchasing a coupon booklet (good for 10 classes) for $30. Full-time students can always pay only $3 to attend. If these options don't work for you, please let me or one of the teachers know and other arrangements can be made.

Please don't be discouraged by the lack of RSVPs - many of our members do not belong to Meetup and so do not RSVP here. There will definitely be a crowd of dancers present!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the red door in the lower level of the church on Sycamore St, and follow the sound of the music!
results.name: Weekly Monday Class

results.description:
Join us on Tuesdays for American Mah Jong! Folks begin arriving around 5PM, and play begins table by table as soon as we have three or four players plus a set.  (We usually have 3-5 tables.)  By 6:15 or so, most players have arrived. We rotate among the tables... at the end of each game, East walks around to see if another table is close to the end of their game, so that two players can swap places.   At the other end of the evening... play must end by 9PM when Panera closes.  Tables begin wrapping up play any time after 8:15 or so.


If you have never played, or if you have not played for a very long time, we highly recommend that you take a Mah Jong 101 beginner class before playing with us - beginner classes are offered every few months.  Mah jong is a wonderful game, but it's hard to learn by just watching others play!


Please order your 2015 card from the National Mah Jongg League, here: http://www.nationalmahjonggleague.org/ Amazon.com also carries the cards. Note that you want the NMJL card, and no other! (There are some colorful alternatives out there.. but we play NMJL card and rules.)

Experienced players -- please bring your cards and please bring a set if you have one.

Please do not bring any outside food or beverages into Panera! Instead, please plan to buy *something* from Panera, even if it's just a beverage or a cookie, to support their willingness to host us.
results.how_to_find_us: Hard to miss us, look for the Mah Jong sets!

results.description:
Experience the magic as Phipps Conservatory brings the beloved "Deck the Halls" holiday carol to life with an all-new show featuring festive evergreens, bright blooms and glowing glass.

Bringing the familiar carol “Deck the Halls” to life, each of the changing exhibit rooms in Phipps will embody the spirit of the holiday tune, complete with artful arrangements of LED lights, decorated fir trees, whimsical props, and, of course, plenty of seasonal favorites such as colorful poinsettias, aromatic paperwhites, showy amaryllis and a jaw-dropping massive evergreen situated in the pond of the Victoria Room. Little ones can also be on the lookout for tiny troll figures hidden throughout the displays, a clever twist on the “troll the ancient yuletide carol” lyric of the song.  

Adding to the festive atmosphere, in our Outdoor and Discovery Gardens, the Winter Light Garden will sparkle with luminous orbs, trees and fountains of light. Garden Railroad will be on view too, taking you on a magical trip through the plots of nine fairy tales and fables brought to life with interactive buttons for children to push, and miniature living plants, shrubs and trees.

Winter Flower Show, designed by Terra Design Studios, LLC, and Winter Light Garden, designed by Phipps Exhibit Coordinator Jordyn Melino, runs through Sun., Jan. 10. Daily hours for Winter Flower Show are 9:30 a.m. – 11 p.m. and 5 – 11 p.m. for Winter Light Garden. Phipps closes at 5 p.m. on Thurs., Dec. 24 and reopens at 9:30 a.m. on Sat., Dec. 26. Admission is $15 for adults, $14 for seniors and students, and $11 for children (ages 2 – 18). Members and kids under 2 enter free. For more information, please visit https://phipps.conservatory.org/calendar/detail/winter-flower-show-and-light-garden 

And experience the indoor gardens which are further enhanced by Candlelight Evenings (with live music during select times through December 23). For more information, please visit https://phipps.conservatory.org/calendar/detail/candlelight-evenings

Phipps is spectacular with all of the gardens, sculptures, holiday displays, lights, etc. while guests enjoy jazz music adding to the ambiance.

People can get food and drinks inside the Cafe, while they also have an outdoor area set up with coffee, hot chocolate, cookies, etc. as well as toasted almonds and even mulled wine!

The Phipps experience is both nostalgic and cutting edge, giving new meaning to "Walking In a Winter Wonderland"

And as visitors tour Phipps, they also learn how Phipps integrates 'world class' green energy and sustainability concepts seamlessly into their artistically designed gardens. http://phipps.conservatory.org/project-green-heart/index.aspx

Extended Daily hours for Winter Flower Show are 9:30 a.m. – 11 p.m. and 5 – 11 p.m. for Winter Light Garden until January 10. Please note Phipps closes at 5 p.m. on Dec. 24 and reopens at 9:30 a.m. on Dec. 26.

Admission is $15 for adults, $14 for seniors and students, and $11 for children (ages 2 – 18). While Phipps Members and kids under 2 enter free.

Because Phipps has so many terrific new exhibits and activities throughout the year, many guests find great value in becoming Phipps Members so they can return often to check out what is new on a more leisurely basis without paying separate admission each time.  Because Phipps memberships start at only $50 per year, this is great  deal.  Treat your family, treat your friends, treat yourself! For more information about Phipps Memberships, please visit http://phipps.conservatory.org/become-a-member/index.aspx

*Inclement Weather Advisory
Winter Light Garden may be subject to temporary closures in the event of heavy rains or other inclement weather conditions.

Toys for Tots
Phipps is proud to be a collection site for Toys for Tots. We encourage you to donate new, unwrapped toys in the Phipps Welcome Center during open hours from Nov. 23 – Dec. 13.

For more information about Phipps Conservatory, please visit http://phipps.conservatory.org

results.name: Phipps Conservatory -- Winter Light Garden and Flower Show

results.description:
Join us for a 2-hour session of indoor volleyball open gym! You'll get a ton of playing time in a well-organized event. Our host will check players in, divide players into teams, and make sure that everything runs smoothly. All you have to do is show up ready to play!

Pricing:

• $7 - RSVP online and pay in advance (online rsvp closes at 4:30 pm!)

• $9 - RSVP and pay cash at the event

• $10 - Show up and play - be sure to check online to make sure there is room!

What to Wear: We are playing indoors on a rubberized all-sport surface. Most players wear volleyball-specific shoes, but gym shoes are also allowed. Please bring your shoes and change into them at the facility. This will help keep the floor clean of dirt and water.

What to Expect: Show up early! The games will begin at the time posted for this event. Players can start checking in with the event host as early as 15 minutes before the scheduled start time. If a court is available, you may begin warming up before the event begins. We limit play to 42 players per evening, which is 3 teams of 7 players per court. If we have 3 teams on a court, winners stay once and then shuffle out so everyone gets to play. If less people are in attendance, we divide based on who is there and mix things up half way through the session.

Level of Play: This event is open to all levels of play. We do our best to create even teams so that games are well-matched. Our ideal scenario is having one court of higher skilled players and one court of more recreational players. There are no referees, so players need to play with sportsmanship and make their own calls. We aim to make everyone feel welcome at these events.

Facility Information: Monroeville Sports Center is located at 855 Macbeth Drive in Monroeville. Parking should be ample in the free lot.

Minimum number of players and playing formats. This event needs a minimum of 12 people (not including the host) signed up before the start of the event in order to run. An email notification will be sent if we cancel. Refunds or credits will be issued if we cancel the event. Sign up early to encourage more people to sign up!!

Do Your Part! Help us keep an accurate guest count! If you RSVP, we're counting on you to be there. If you change your mind about playing or your guest count changes, please update your RSVP. No-Shows will be marked on your account. If space is tight, we hold RSVP spots 10 minutes into advertised start and then open spots to walk-ups.

Requirements to play: This is an adult volleyball group. You must be 19 older. Males and females of all skill levels are welcome to play. There is no required gender ratio. Players are expected to conduct themselves with good sportsmanship.

What's included in the price? Your payment helps to cover the rental costs, the hourly pay for your event host, and ensures a well-organized event.

Questions? Post your question in the comments section of this meetup and the event host or one of our organizers will reply. You can also message the organizers directly through meetup. Or, give us a call M-F 8:00am-12:30pm:[masked]-7130.

This is not a formal meetup. We share this information with you because it is a metaphysics event in Pittsburgh that you may enjoy attending.

Due to the broken furnace at Union Project, the clinic will be held at Ola's Herb Shop.  The address is above.  This is a smaller space and it may limit some of what we offer.  We still hope that you all can make it and that you will benefit from coming.

The shop is located above Ten Thousand Villages.  The entrance is to the left of Ten Thousand Villages (same entrance as Mediterranean Grill).

Here the details about the event:

Potology – Wisdom through Ceramic Pots - by Marike

Potology is a method to learn more about yourself through the features in the pots you select consciously and subconsciously. Great wisdom can be attained by this natural method of gaining insights into your life.

Potology Sessions are offered at the

Three Rivers Free Clinic for the People

First Wednesday of Every Month

* 1pm - 7pm *

Union Project: Great Hall

801 N Negley Avenue

Pittsburgh, PA 15206

Contact information:
Tel:[masked]
​Mail: [masked]

Visit our Facebook Page!

Please contact us if you plan to attend and would like to receive holistic health services (or if you would like to volunteer).

Location & Hours

About the entire event

THREE RIVERS FREE CLINIC FOR THE PEOPLE!

A holistic health FREE clinic serving the people in Pittsburgh and surrounding areas.

Jan. 7 Schedule of Services to be posted soon.

Mission

Three Rivers Free Clinic for the People is a community service for individuals unable to afford or easily access to holistic healthcare. Together we deliver the future of healthcare by caring for the community who represent our individual well being for the sake of the generations to come.

Description

Three Rivers Free Clinic for the People or TRFCP, is a community based service concerning individuals unable to afford or have easy access to holistic healthcare. Developed to support our elders who represent our roots and traditions, warriors who represent and defend our nation, "tree" women who represent the diversity of women who struggle through sexual, physical, mental and emotional abuse, and children in need, who represent our future and inspiration.

The vision of TRFCP is supported by Herbalist's without Borders, The Union Project and Ola's Herb Shop who have collaborated with the understanding that the importance to provide this kind of space to support all members of the community is paramount. All people reflect our individual selves, therefore our societal health. In addition, access to holistic health interventions are not always accessible and available to everyone, yet are traditionally and scientifically proven to be highly effective forms of healing from which many can benefit.

The clinic will be available once a month and individuals will sign-up or have scheduled visits (particularly groups coming from a facility or organization).

Current days are every first Wednesday of the month, hours 1-7p.

Expect to be supported by volunteer practitioner(s) of holistic health who may provide botanical therapy, meditation, Reiki, intuitive counseling, yoga, massage therapy, reflexology and much more depending on the needs of the people and the practitioners who have volunteered their services for that day.

It is our hope that all forms of donations, through service, volunteer work or financial bases from interested members of the community, will sustain this vision because it is forseen to create a paradigm shift in community healthcare and delivery for the sake of us all.
results.name: Potology Sessions at the Three Rivers Free Clinic for the People - NEW LOCATION

This game is looking for players. "Deadlands: The Weird West" is a setting
where steam-powered jetpacks and zeppelins share space with cowboys,
sharp-eyed prospectors, and smoky desert saloons while inhuman
abominations and unsettling mysteries hide in every shadow.
 1876. The American Civil War has been going for 17 years with
no end in sight, and now being fought with steam-powered
tanks, flying machines, and man-portable Gatling rifles. The Quake of
 smashed California into a labyrinth of shattered plateaus and
treacherous rapids known as the "Great Maze", and the Sioux Nations
have reclaimed the Dakotas.
 Rumors have spread across the nation that the West is beset by
everything from giant, man-eating bats to the walking dead, and while
people in more civilized parts of the continent think  all
bunk,  mostly because the Union and Confederate governments
have done their best to hide the facts from them: truth is, magic and
monsters are very, very real, and there are larger forces behind their
sudden return.
 Anyone is free to join, regardless of prior experience: just walk in
and ask. I can be contacted through my e-mail or at[masked] (aim
for 11:30 AM to 5:30 PM) and am happy to help with character creation,
take suggestions on what mood or tone you would like to see in the
game, and answer questions.

results.description:
We will be reading Winter Street by Elin Hilderbrand over the Holidays as our Primary Book.   For those who would like to read a second book since we won't be meeting in December the second choice is An Island Christmas by Nancy Thayer.  We will be discussing Winter Street first in January and then secondly An Island Christmas for those that read both. Below are descriptions of both.

Winter Street Description:

Kelley Quinn is the owner of Nantucket's Winter Street Inn and the proud father of four grown children: Patrick, a hedge fund manager; Kevin, a bartender; Ava, a school teacher; and Bart, who has recently shocked everyone by joining the Marines. As Christmas approaches, Kelley looks forward to spending the holidays with his family at the inn. But when he walks in on his wife Mitzi kissing another man, utter chaos descends, and things only get more interesting when Kelley's ex-wife, news anchor Margaret Quinn, arrives on the scene.  Before the mulled cider is gone, the delightfully dysfunctional Quinn family will survive a love triangle, an unplanned pregnancy, a federal crime, and endless rounds of Christmas caroling in this heart-warming novel about coming home for the holidays.

An Island Christmas Description:

In this enchanting holiday novel from New York Times bestselling author Nancy Thayer, family and friends gather on Nantucket for a gorgeous winter wedding with plenty of merry surprises in store.

As Christmas draws near, Felicia returns to her family’s home on the island to marry her adventurous, rugged boyfriend, Archie. Every detail is picture-perfect for a dream wedding: the snow-dusted streets, twinkling lights in the windows, a gorgeous red and white satin dress. Except a lavish ceremony is not Felicia’s dream at all; it’s what her mother, Jilly, wants. Jilly’s also worried that her daughter’s life with daredevil Archie will be all hiking and skydiving. Wondering if their handsome neighbor Steven Hardy might be a more suitable son-in-law, Jilly embarks on a secret matchmaking campaign for Felicia and the dashing stockbroker.

As the big day approaches and Jilly’s older daughter, Lauren, appears with rambunctious kids in tow, tensions in the household are high. With the family careening toward a Yuletide wedding disaster, an unexpected twist in Nancy Thayer’s heartwarming tale reminds everyone about the true meaning of the season.

Please Bring a Chick Lit/Women's Fiction book (that is out in paperback)! Not sure what to bring?

Here is the definition of Chick Lit: Chick lit is genre fiction within women's fiction which addresses issues of modern women often humorously and lightheartedly*

Here is the definition of Women's Fiction: a modern novel about a woman on the brink of life change and personal growth. Her journey details emotional reflection and action that transforms her and her relationships with others, and  usually includes a hopeful/upbeat ending with regard to her romantic relationship.

results.description:
From Amazon: 83% of 435 people rated it 4 or 5 stars


It was a glittering, sumptuous time when hypocrisy was expected, discreet infidelity tolerated, and unconventionality ostracized.

That is the Gilded Age, and nobody knew its hypocrises better than Edith Wharton.... and nobody portrayed them as well. "The Age of Innocence" is a trip back in time to the stuffy upper crust of "old New York," taking us through one respectable man's hopeless love affair with a beautiful woman -- and the life he isn't brave enough to have.

Newland Archer, of a wealthy old New York family, has become engaged to pretty, naive May Welland. But as he tries to get their wedding date moved up, he becomes acquainted with May's exotic cousin, Countess Ellen Olenska, who has returned home after dumping her cheating husband. At first, the two are just friends, but Newland becomes more and more entranced by the Countess' easy, free-spirited European charm.

After Newland marries May, the attraction to the mysterious Countess and her free, unconventional life becomes even stronger. He starts to rebel in little ways, but he's still mired in a 100% conventional marriage, job and life. Will he become an outcast and go away with the beautiful countess, or will he stick with May and the safe, dull life that he has condemned in others?

There's nothing too scandalous about "Age of Innocence" in a time when starlets acquire and discard boyfriends and husbands like old pantyhose -- it probably wasn't in the 1920s when it was first published. But then, this isn't a book about sexiness and steam -- it's part bittersweet romance, part social satire, and a look at what happens when human beings lose all spontaneity and passion
results.name: The Age of Innocence by Edith Warton

 Atelier de conversation & prononciation

Vous avez de bonnes connaissances en français mais vous ressentez des difficultés à vous exprimer ? Vous souhaiteriez vous exprimer de manière plus naturelle ? Votre priorité d’apprentissage est l’interaction orale ? N’attendez pas plus longtemps pour vous inscrire dans notre cours de conversation. Vous y apprendrez à développer vos compétences en communication orale à travers des débats, des échanges en français, des jeux de rôle autour de thèmes que vous pourrez choisir avec votre professeur : actualité, société, culture, etc. A l'issue de cet atelier vous serez plus à l'aise à l’oral et plus confiant(e) lorsque vous discuterez avec vos amis ou collègues francophones.

Event will begin at 7:00pm

YOU ARE MORE THAN JUST YOUR SUN SIGN!

The time has come for humanity to comprehend the full brilliance of the zodiac’s grand design. The energies that comprise each of us are the very same energies that make up the whole universe.   Please join us as 

Rick DiClemente gives an overview of his new book, The Exquisite Zodiac, and reveals how every facet of the zodiac works in sync, and how we can apply the entirety of its intelligence and wisdom in a practical way.

The Exquisite Zodiac bridges the gap between abstract, esoteric astrology books and those that are glib and misleading—thereby setting astrology on the proper track for our time. After this evening, you will never view astrology—or yourself and your relationships—in the same way again. 

Rick DiClemente is not your typical astrologer. Widely known as a “way shower,” he blends math-science and spiritual-psychic ability with empirical knowledge in order to reveal the multi-faceted story in each chart. Rick’s intuitive-astrological readings blend past-life experience with the natal chart as well as your dharmic, or destiny chart.  At the same time, he brings alive the applied discipline of consulting with the cosmos for timeless wisdom that helps others better understand themselves, their relationships and their lives.

Rick has practiced astrology for 36 years, he works on radio, TV and the Internet and has presented numerous lectures, classes, workshops and online videos. He is the author of “The Exquisite Zodiac” and his articles appear monthly in national and international magazines.

 To learn more or to schedule a private consultation, visit www.starself.com.

results.description:
I came across this book while browsing a reddit thread on books that changed people's lives. Once I read a bit about it, I definitely had to throw it on my reading list, especially since it seems to capture the same essence of whimsy and loss of innocence as Alice in Wonderland. It also didn't hurt that Neil Gaiman and Peter S. Beagle gave it wonderful reviews.

Synopsis: September is a twelve-year-old girl, Somewhat Grown and Somewhat Heartless, and she longs for adventure. So when a Green Wind and a Leopard of Little Breezes invite her to Fairyland - well, of course, she accepts (mightn't you?). When she gets there, she finds a land crushed by the iron rule of a villainous Marquess - she soon discovers that she alone holds the key to restoring order. As September forges her way through Fairyland, with a book-loving dragon and a boy named Saturday by her side, she makes many friends and mistakes. But while she loses her shadow, her shoe, and her way, she finds adventure, courage, a rather special Spoon, and a lot more besides...


Also, check out this book's trailer!

Approx. Page Count: 247


Location: I figured Eden would be a nice place to discuss a book about the loss of innocence. Eden is a very unique and tasty restaurant in Shadyside with creative vegan/raw food cuisine.
results.name: The Girl Who Circumnavigated Fairyland by Catherynne M. Valente

I'll be giving a beginner swing lesson starting at 7:15.  So don't worry if you don't know how to dance, I'll teach you the basics!  Whether you're new to dancing or have some experience, the lesson is a GREAT way to meet and make new friends.  We rotate partners in class, which creates a great learning environment and gives you a chance to meet other folks.

Our crowd grows every time!  We had a really FANTASTIC group the last time!!

Air Conditioned / FREE parking
$7.00 cover.

Come on out & DANCE!

Whether you just want to enjoy the sounds of big band music or do some dancing, come join us at the Elks on the North Side. Cover ONLY $7.  $2 drafts!!

Just ask for Mark, you'll have no trouble finding me.

This month it is 1st and 3rd Thursday.

"Coffee" after support group started sometime ago with just 2 people and now has grown to a regular event 3 times a month. While we call it "coffee", it is anything goes from just a drink to a full meal. For the Thursday meeting we always go to Eat N Park afterwards.  Remember this meet up happens after the support group at:

Christ United Methodist Church

PRIME TIME 'B'

44 Highland Road, Bethel Park (across from Village Square)

THIRD Church DRIVEWAY on Highland (coming from Route 19)

7:30pm-9:00pm  (2nd and 4th Thursday, except when there is a holiday)

This is different than the one at Bridgeville Library located at 505 McMillen St, Bridgeville, PA which meets on first Tuesday at an earlier time.  

"Coffee" will be immediately following this group.  The library support group is open to the public, but sharing the details in a public area is discouraged.  Please keep in mind this meet up is not intended to suggest a meet up at the support group.  Just remember everyone is welcome at both the support group and "coffee".

results.description:
Yes, I am a financial planner, yes I work for New York Life,and Yes I was a former police officer, but the absolute most important thing to me is that you get ironclad financial information you can feel good about. Information that can guarantee income for life, information that will protect your assets from probate and taxes, information that can secure and protect your assets for the best way to transfer wealth. There are some very simple strategies that you just can't afford to overlook, strategies that will have a life changing impact on your future that will last for generations. Strategies that you will literally say "wow" to.
Sure, this is networking, but you are not going to hurt my feeling if I all get out of this is a new introduction. I just hate to see hard working people be taken advantage of and missing the boat on some very simple, no cost fix-it advice. . 

 I like coffee as much as the next person, and I will be glad to buy you a good cup and discuss anything on your mind. Locations will vary from time to time, most likely different or suggested coffee shops in the surrounding areas.

results.description:
Get Heard! Get Noticed! Get Leads! (TM)

Hosted by: Amber Spells of AMS Consulting Group and Maryann Liddle from Liddle Architectural Design

This is an informal networking event, open to any business woman who would like to increase her business contacts or clients in the Robinson/Airport area.

Things to bring:

- 10-20 business cards or marketing material

- cash for your lunch check

- $5 meeting fee (non members only)

AGENDA

1:00 pm - attendees arrive, reviews menu, gives the server their drink order, and open networking: everyone stands up to introduce oneself to others and pass their business card

1:15 pm - server takes lunch order and the sign in sheet is passed around

1:30 pm - 60 sec. commercials begin

2:00 pm - each person gives a testimony or referral for someone attending the lunch

2:30 pm - Premier member does a 5 min. company presentation

2:35 pm - WSBA announcements from Debi/Susan

2:45 pm - lunch has ended. Open networking is welcomed.

Be prepared to do a 60 second commercial about yourself. Please RSVP if you plan to attend this lunch. If your schedule becomes free the day of the lunch, then you may attend without an RSVP. This lunch is subject to cancellation when the lunch has 3 or less RSVPs.Lunch cancellation policy.

If you are not a WSBA member and would like to attend as a guest, please contact  <a>Debi Arnett</a>  at [masked]

If you have an interest in becoming a General member ($50/year) or Premier member ($100/year) of WSBA, please contact  <a>Debi Arnett</a> at [masked]

Any non member that RSVPs and does not attend will be removed from this sight.

*This event is cross posted with the Greensburg Happy Hour meetup*

   Jason, the organizer for Greensburg Happy Hour, has graciously requested our coordination to attend the "Art on Tap" (practically "happy hour" at the museum) at the Westmoreland Museum of American Art in Greensburg. Here are the details taken directly from the museum's website, "Experience happy hour at The Westmoreland the second Friday of every month. Enjoy music by Jane West, a scavenger hunt, light bites from The Pier at Sharky’s and drinks—including beer from All Saints Brewing Company. This month’s Art on Tap is sponsored by SkySight Photography." 


Tickets are $10 and can be purchased here: http://thewestmoreland.org/event/art-on-tap-jan-2016/

After seeing the museum last year, I highly recommend it!
Thanks, and I look forward to seeing everyone there!
results.name: A Night at the Museum

results.description:
Hello everyone!

Looking forward to some great turnouts for the 2016 Friday Night under the Lights!  

I know it has been a while since our last meetup but with the holidays falling on Fridays this year it has caused a delay in some of our regularly scheduled events.  The 5:00 PM start time seemed to be a big hit at the last meetup so I will continue to start at that time.  If you can't come early no worries we will be playing games until 11:00 PM and you are welcome to join for as long as you can come or stay. 

Games played at the last meetup included:  Orleans, Steampunk Ralley, Splendor, Shadows over Camelot, and many more.  Once again 11:00 PM came way too soon but we all had a great time.  

This week's featured theme is:  Bring your favorite game! 

Once again I am going to bring out:  Orleans!  It is a fairly new game with a unique mechanic called "Bag Building" and I really enjoyed my first play of it.

I have lined up another venue that we can try out in Bridgeville but I am a little hesitant to list it yet until I get the consensus that people would like to come to that venue.  I would also like to ensure that we have at least 12 people attend so we can obtain the entire back room.  They stay open until 1:30 so it would give us a later evening.

Please r.s.v.p. early so I have an idea on how many people or coming and what games to bring along.  You can always cancel your r.s.v.p. if you have a change of plans.


See you on Friday!

Russ.
results.name: Friday Night under the Lights!

Every woman gets a padlock. Every man gets a key. Your goal is to match the right key with the right padlock. results.description:
Ce soir je passe le film L'esquive du cinéaste Abdellatif Kechiche.  C'est un film qui s'inspire du Jeu de l'amour et de l'hasard de Marivaux.  

"Abdelkrim, dit Krimo, quinze ans, vit dans une cité HLM de la banlieue parisienne. Il partage avec sa mère, employée dans un supermarché, et son père, en prison, un grand rêve fragile : partir sur un voilier au bout du monde.
En attendant, il traîne son ennui dans un quotidien banal de cité, en compagnie de son meilleur ami, Eric, et de leur bande de copains. C'est le printemps et Krimo tombe sous le charme de sa copine de classe Lydia, une pipelette vive et malicieuse..." 

Friday is film night.

I will showing the movie at our home in Wexford this time. Make sure to update your rsvp so you can receive the exact address and directions to our house.  No last minute drop-ins.

I will only mail out the exact address and contact number to people who definitely rsvp. I will provide the film name (or selection) tonight also.  


- I’m showing another favorite film.  Will put some thought into it and post it tonight. Any requests?  I have a lot of fun films no one has heard of (at least in the States).  I’ll post a list later today.

We will be doing fondue and wine.

Still time to RSVP until tomorrow afternoon.

Event is Free


Marc

results.description:
Meet in lobby starting at 7:30; film starts at 8.

$9
A screenie pass gets you 12 films (and a free popcorn or soda!) for only $80: http://cinema.pfpca.org/screenie-subscription


In 1966, French director Francois Truffaut published a series of in-depth conversations he had with Alfred Hitchcock in the classic book Hitchcock/Truffaut, which chronicled the details and mastery of Hitchcock’s extensive body of work. Based on the original recordings of their conversations, this documentary is a film buff’s dream; illustrating the greatest cinema lesson of all time, it plummets us into the world of the creator of Psycho, The Birds, and Vertigo. Hitchcock’s incredibly modern art and enduring legacy is elucidated by today’s leading filmmakers: Martin Scorsese, David Fincher, Arnaud Desplechin, Kiyoshi Kurosawa, Wes Anderson, James Gray, Olivier Assayas, Richard Linklater, Peter Bogdanovich and Paul Schrader.

Kent Jones | USA | 2015 | 90 minutes


Trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hgAvkXH4dmI
results.name: Hitchcock Truffaut @ Regent Square Theater

Alex and team

results.description:
The extremely unique, 19,000 square foot museum (the former home of Mr. Charles B. Brown, III, the museum's founder) houses a large collection of music boxes and other fascinating automatic musical instruments, as well as many other interesting items. The building itself provides guests with a most interesting experience as they pass from room to room, at times through hidden doors and secret passages.

Almost the entire south side of the house is glass, affording fantastic views up and down the Allegheny River.

Admission is only $10.00 per person.

Tours are limited to 12 people.   Please be ready to pay in cash.  

TOURS ARE BY APPOINTMENT ONLY AND MUST BE SCHEDULED BEFORE ARRIVING AT THE MUSEUM.


http://www.bayernhofmuseum.com


2 hour walking tour, NOT handicap accessible.  There were only 2 tour times, 10 am or 2 pm.   We have to be there at 9:45.  I know it seems early but you can do it!

Visitors Always Welcome

The Pittsburgh Area Model Club is sponsored by the Pittsburgh Chapter for the purpose of teaching investment club operations and BetterInvesting investment decision-making techniques.

Visitors are always welcome, and on occasion out number members. Bring your whole club, if you wish.

Anyone in the Chapter area can attend as a visitor, and is eligible to apply for membership. Visitors are encouraged to participate in our lively discussions (but only members may vote on investment decisions for the club).

Each member invests between $10 and $100 per month, and the club maintains an investment portfolio following BetterInvesting procedures.

Prerequisite:
A desire to improve your investment decisions.

results.description:
Free Family-Friendly Brown Bag Concert

You're invited to a free Brown Bag concert as Pittsburgh Opera's Resident Artists perform a very special program highlighting some of opera's greatest hits. This concert presents 'a few of our favorite things' with a selection of favorite operatic arias, spanning a delightful range of works including Carmen, La Traviata, and Rigoletto. And to top it off, you’ll also be treated to a sneak preview of an excerpt from Pittsburgh Opera's wonderful upcoming production of Little Women during January 23-31, 2016.

January 9, 2016
  12:00 PM - 1:00 PM 
  
Location: 2425 Liberty Avenue, in the Strip District

Free and open to the public, these monthly one-hour concerts feature Pittsburgh Opera Resident Artists in the George R. White Opera Studio at Pittsburgh Opera  Headquarters. Bring a friend and bring your lunch!  There is is usually complimentary coffee, tea, and cookies.

Doors open at 11:30 AM.  Please note that the Pittsburgh Opera  garage is available only for handicapped parking, by reservation. RESERVATIONS MUST BE RECEIVED BY 4:00 PM FRIDAY, January 8.

For more information about this Brown Bag Concert, please visit  http://pittsburghopera.org/calendar/detail/january-brown-bag-concert

For more information about Pittsburgh Opera and the complete line-up for the[masked] season, please visit http://pittsburghopera.org

So whether you're curious or just looking to take a little break while shopping in the Strip, please consider stopping by Pittsburgh Opera to enjoy their resident artists as they sing classics to give guests a little taste of opera.

And if you're relatively new to Meetup, this would be a nice event to attend to meet lots of people in a very relaxed, convenient setting.  Because the concert ends at 1 PM, your Saturday afternoon will still be open. Depending on the RSVPs and interests of the group, some people may decide to go out for an optional lunch or just walk around the Strip District checking out some places.

Because we're expecting a large group, we'll also discuss various options for those that wish to continue their afternoon in the Strip District. For example, we may have 5-30+ Meetup members that might like to check out a few more things (say from 1:30- 5 PM) with the group.

Options for Spending Time in the Strip District After the Concert

In addition to many interesting restaurants, shops, bars, etc.,  there are some other great places within a short walk of the Pittsburgh Opera location:

1) Heinz History Center & Western Pennsylvania Sports Museum (1212 Smallman Street) -- which includes the incredible We Can Do It! WWII Exhibit that was just extended another week until January 10, 2016. It is very impressive covering WWII and Pittsburgh's role (such as local companies that manufactured the Jeep and many other products for the military), the role of women, impact of WWII on everyday life (such as ration books) in the U.S., etc.  Here is the link with all of the details http://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/exhibits/we-can-do-it-wwii They even have a Sherman tank parked outside as part of the exhibit!  For more information about all the exhibits at the Heinz History Center, please visit http://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/ Here is the visitor guide (to all 7 floors of incredible galleries) http://www.heinzhistorycenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/History-Center-Visitor-Guide-2015-April.pdf Admission is Adults ($16); Senior Citizens 62+ ($14); Retired & Active Duty Military ($6.50); Students with a valid school ID ($6.50); Children ages 6-17 ($6.50); Children ages 5 and under (Free)

2) Society for Contemporary Craft (2100 Smallman Street) http://contemporarycraft.org/ which contains the remarkable exhibit Mindful: Exploring Mental Health through Art (September 18, 2015 - March 12, 2016) http://contemporarycraft.org/exhibition/mindful/ Admission is free although a suggested donation of $5 is also OK.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in lobby at 11:30-11:45 AM before the noon performance. These concerts draw big crowds, so please get there early. We'll also gather in the lobby after the show for coffee/tea/cookies -- and decide other group options (1-5 PM) discussed below.
results.name: Free Brown Bag Concert -- Opera's Greatest Hits
